text: Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shall be measured to you again.
text_kjv: Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shall be measured to you again.
text_niv: Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together and running over, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you.”
text_esv: give, and it will be given to you. Good measure, pressed down, shaken together, running over, will be put into your lap. For with the measure you use it will be measured back to you.”
text_nlt: Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full — pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The amount you give will determine the amount you get back. ”
text_msg: Give away your life; you'll find life given back, but not merely given back—given back with bonus and blessing. Giving, not getting, is the way. Generosity begets generosity."
text_nasb: 'Give, and it will be given to you. They will pour into your lap a good measure-- pressed down, shaken together, [and] running over. For by your standard of measure it will be measured to you in return.'
context: In first-century Palestine, the concept of giving and receiving was deeply intertwined with agricultural practices and social obligations. Grain, a staple food, was measured using various containers and standards. Luke's Gospel, written to a primarily Gentile audience, seeks to explain Jesus' teachings within a relatable context. When Jesus speaks of 'good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and running over,' He's evoking the image of merchants who would go the extra mile to ensure the customer received full value. A 'bosom' wasn't a literal part of the anatomy, but rather the fold in the upper part of the garment that was used as a pouch or pocket to carry goods. This imagery painted a vivid picture of abundance and return. Reciprocity was a fundamental principle in that society. Giving alms to the poor, providing hospitality to strangers, and honoring religious leaders were all expected behaviors that contributed to the social and economic well-being of the community. The expectation was that such acts of generosity would be reciprocated, either directly or indirectly. The phrase 'same measure' alludes to the judicial context of fair weights and measures, highlighting the importance of honesty and integrity in transactions. This verse is part of Jesus' Sermon on the Plain (Luke 6:20-49), where he contrasts his teachings with conventional wisdom, urging his followers to adopt a radical approach to love, forgiveness, and generosity, even towards their enemies. The immediate context involves loving one's enemies and lending without expecting repayment, setting the stage for the broader principle of generous giving that Jesus is about to expound. Giving was never viewed as a burden, but rather as an opportunity to participate in the divine economy, where God rewards those who are generous and compassionate.
meaning: Luke 6:38 is a profound statement about the spiritual principle of sowing and reaping. It suggests that generosity is not a one-way street but rather a cycle of giving and receiving initiated by God. The 'good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and running over' signifies an abundant and overflowing return, far exceeding what was initially given. The image of grain being carefully measured and filled to the brim emphasizes the completeness and generosity of God's blessings. The phrase 'shall men give into your bosom' refers to receiving the return from others, possibly suggesting a communal aspect to this principle. The verse connects this reciprocal relationship to the concept of 'measure for measure,' indicating that the degree of generosity we extend to others will determine the degree of blessing we receive. This is not a mechanical formula, but rather a reflection of God's justice and grace. A generous heart aligns itself with God's character, making it receptive to His blessings. Jesus isn't just talking about material wealth, but also about spiritual blessings like joy, peace, and fulfillment. When we are generous with our time, talents, and resources, we create space in our lives for God to pour out His blessings. The emphasis is on the heart of the giver. God is not looking for calculated donations, but rather for sincere acts of compassion motivated by love. The verse invites us to examine our attitudes toward giving and to consider whether we are holding back out of fear or selfishness. True generosity stems from a deep trust in God's provision and a desire to be a channel of His blessings to others. The blessing that returns isn't always predictable, it may manifest in unexpected ways. The focus should be on the act of giving from the right heart.
application: In modern application, Luke 6:38 challenges us to examine our attitudes towards generosity in all areas of life. It's easy to focus on financial giving, but this verse also applies to our time, talents, love, forgiveness, and encouragement. Are we generous with our time in serving others? Do we freely share our talents to benefit our community? Are we quick to forgive those who have wronged us? Do we offer words of encouragement to those who are struggling? Practically, this means looking for opportunities to give generously, even when it's inconvenient or requires sacrifice. This could involve volunteering at a local charity, donating to a cause we believe in, offering a helping hand to a neighbor, or simply listening attentively to a friend in need. It also means cultivating a generous spirit, releasing control and trusting God's provision. We often hold back out of fear that we won't have enough for ourselves, but Jesus promises that when we give generously, God will provide more than enough. However, it's important to approach this verse with the right motives. We shouldn't give with the expectation of receiving a specific return, but rather out of a genuine desire to bless others and honor God. This verse isn't a get-rich-quick scheme, but rather a principle that operates on a deeper level. God is more interested in our heart than our bank account. Furthermore, we must be wise stewards of the resources God has given us. Generosity shouldn't lead to financial irresponsibility. We should give thoughtfully and intentionally, focusing on causes that align with our values and contribute to the well-being of others. Reflect on the areas where you may be holding back. What fears or insecurities are preventing you from giving generously? Ask God to reveal opportunities for you to give more freely and to cultivate a heart of compassion. Practice intentional acts of generosity each day, starting with small gestures and gradually increasing as you grow in faith. Remember that true generosity isn't just about giving things away; it's about giving of ourselves.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the generous gift of your Son, Jesus Christ, who gave his life for us. Help us to reflect your generosity in our own lives. Forgive us for the times when we have been stingy or selfish, holding back out of fear or insecurity. Open our eyes to the opportunities you provide for us to give generously of our time, talents, and resources. Fill our hearts with compassion for those in need and empower us to be channels of your blessings to others. May our giving be motivated by love and gratitude, not by a desire for reward. Teach us to trust in your provision and to believe that you will always supply our needs. Guide us to be wise stewards of what you have entrusted to us, so that we may give freely and joyfully. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, Luke 6:38 is not a guarantee of automatic financial riches. While financial blessings may result from generosity, the primary emphasis is on a spiritual principle: generous giving opens us to receive God's abundant blessings, which include but are not limited to financial prosperity. Focus on genuine generosity.
faqs.question: Does this verse guarantee financial wealth if I give?

faqs.answer: This phrase describes a method of measuring grain in ancient times. The person measuring would pack the grain tightly ('pressed down') and shake the container to settle the contents ('shaken together') to maximize the amount given. It symbolizes a generous and overflowing measure, exceeding expectations.
faqs.question: What does it mean by 'good measure, pressed down, and shaken together'?

faqs.answer: No, Luke 6:38 extends far beyond monetary donations. It encompasses all forms of giving, including time, talents, kindness, forgiveness, and encouragement. The principle applies to any act of generosity, big or small, that benefits others and honors God.
faqs.question: Is this verse only about giving money?

faqs.answer: The 'same measure' implies that the degree of generosity we extend to others will be reflected in the blessings we receive. It highlights the principle of reciprocity and suggests that God is just in rewarding generosity. It also encourages a fair and honest approach in all our dealings.
faqs.question: What does 'same measure' mean?

faqs.answer: Yes, your responsibility lies in the act of giving with a pure heart. While you should exercise wisdom and discernment in your giving, the misuse of your gift by another person does not negate the principle of Luke 6:38. Your generosity is still pleasing to God, and He will honor your intention.
faqs.question: If I give to someone who misuses what I give, does this verse still apply?
